PwIrnxjP.title: Experimental investigation on performance improvement of electro-osmotic regeneration for solid desiccant
PwIrnxjP.abstract: Research highlights ► We investigated four measures to enhance the electro-osmotic regeneration system. ► The use of platinum-plated titanium anode effectively improved the work lifetime. ► Application of filter cloth could significantly enhance the regeneration rate. ► The interrupted power was found to enhance the regeneration rate up to 1.5 times. ► Optimal electric field strength ranges from 8.5 to 13 Vcm −1 in regeneration system. Abstract Electro-osmotic regeneration for the solid desiccant has been proved to have many merits such as regeneration without the heat source; energy-saving and simple structure. However; the previous work has revealed that its performance is seriously limited by the severe Joule heating effect and electrode corrosion; which demands further improvement to meet the practical requirement. In this paper; four possible improvement methods are investigated experimentally; including changing the material of anode; changing layout of cathode; applying the interrupted power and optimizing the electrical field strength. Through detailed experiments and analysis; we found that applying the platinum-plated titanium mesh as anode could improve the working lifetime from 6 h to over 120 h and effectively reduce Joule heating effect simultaneously; laying a piece of filter cloth under the cathode could enhance the EO regeneration rate up to 0.0021 g s −1 ; the application of interrupted power could increase the regeneration rate up to 1.5 times; the optimal on–off-time was found at 30 s:1.3 s with 17 V cm −1 electric field strength and 30 s:0.8 s with 11 V cm −1 ; and the most suitable value of electric field strength was observed as ranging from 8.5 to 13 V cm −1 in our EO regeneration system. Keywords Electro-osmotic Regeneration Solid desiccant Improvement Nomenclature E 0 applied electric field (V) EO electro-osmotic (–) m ˙ water removal rate (kg s −1 ) Subscripts weg by electro-osmotic and gravitational force wg by gravitational force we by electro-osmotic effect 1 Introduction Since the outbreak of SARS in 2003; and the recent outbreak of H1N1 these years; people pay more attentions to the indoor air quality [1] . Because of the separate control of latent load to make a more comfortable indoor environment; the desiccant dehumidification air-conditioning system has drawn increasing attentions [2,3] . And it also has other strong points such as the energy-saving; the reduction of the use of chlorofluorocarbons and so on [4–6] . To make the desiccant work repeatedly; regeneration components are required in the dehumidification systems; which are encouraged to be driven by the waste or renewable energy. [7,8] . The electro-osmotic (EO) regeneration; which has been concerned by many researchers these years; was first proposed in 2004. This novel regeneration method is proposed to regenerate the solid desiccant in a humidity independent control system; with the application of EO force generated by the external electric field. In 2004; Mina and Newell [9] conducted a primary theoretical research about the EO regeneration and found it feasible in the theoretical analysis. In 2007; Zhang and Yu [10] put a zeolite desiccant with an electric field into a high humidity box. However; no water was removed from the desiccant in their experiment. In 2010; Qi et al. [11] validated the possibility of the EO regeneration with the artificial zeolite desiccant experimentally; and the maximum regeneration rate observed was 1.1 × 10 −7 kg m −1 s −1 V −1 . In their investigation; the whole process of EO regeneration was found to be divided into three phases. However; in the preliminary work; the performance of the EO regeneration system was found to be seriously impaired because of the Joule heating effect and electrode corrosion. The Joule heating effect; which was caused by the high initial current; led to a considerable reduction of the water removal rate in the first 2–3 h. The electrode corrosion; which is generated by the electrolytic reactions; not only substantially limited the lifetime of the system; but also reduced the water removal rate. Moreover; the layout of the electrode was considered to play a significant role in the EO regeneration; which required further experiments and investigations to determine the details. And the effect of electric field strength also required further research to find out the optimum parameters. In conclusion; in order to improve the potential of the EO regeneration system for practical application; a system with better performance; including longer work life; higher regeneration rate and stability; is expected. In this essay; we developed and verified four methods to enhance the performance of the EO regeneration system by detailed experiments; including changing the material of anode; changing the layout of cathode; introducing the interrupted power and changing the electrical field strength. During the tests; the optimal control parameters of the improvements were also investigated. 2 Test bench As shown in the Fig. 1 ; the brief principle of the EO regeneration method is because of the rearrangement of the ions; the adsorbed water in the internal channel of the solid desiccant is driven by the electro-osmotic force from the anode to the cathode [11] . According to the previous research; the mean benefits of the EO regeneration are: (1) no heat source required; (2) simple structure (only a DC power supply needed); (3) suitable for renewable energy application. Fig. 2 shows a schematic of the EO regeneration system. The sample box is filled with the artificial zeolite powder (Radius: 200–250 μm). A DC power supply is used to provide specified electric field across the electrodes; which is located on the top and bottom surface of the sample. The relative humidity of the test chamber is maintained at 95 ± 3%; with the continuous inputting moist air generated by a supersonic oscillation humidifier. The measurement devices applied in this experiment are listed in Table 1 . During the experiment; all the required data were collected by a data logger and then delivered to a computer in every five minutes. It is noted that both EO and gravitational forces could remove water from the solid desiccant. So the amount of the removed water should be measured in the condition with and without the electric field to calculate the water removal rate by only electro-osmosis; which is the most significant assessment parameter of the performance. The first step of the experiment is: According to the different methods; adjust the experimental system; including changing the applied electric field strength; the structure of the sample box; the material of anode and introducing the interrupted power. The detailed adjustments were listed in the following parts of this essay. The following steps of the test are similar to our previous experiments; which are shown in the literature [11] . In all the sub-tests listed in part 3–6; the thickness of the sample between two electrodes was 15 mm; and the desiccant powder about 5 mm thick was covered above the anode. The porosity of the desiccant was kept around 80% after the adsorption period (Step (1) in [11] ). For further discussion; the water removal rate by electro-osmosis ( m ˙ we ; g s −1 ) is defined as the difference between the water quantity removed by gravity and that removed by both EO and gravitational forces per unit time ( m ˙ weg ; g s −1 ). 3 Anode material 3.1 Methodology In 2007; Sivapullaiah found that the electrode corrosion caused rapid increase of resistance in the EO soil concretion; which could be avoided by anti-corrosion electrodes [12] . However; whether the result can be applied in EO regeneration for solid desiccant needs further verification. Two types of anode; the conventional stainless steel mesh and the platinum-plated titanium mesh; were tested. Platinum was chosen for its excellent anti-corrosion performance in electro-osmotic pump applications [13] . However; the high cost of pure platinum anode prohibits the widespread use of it; especially in practical projects. So we selected titanium; which is considered as an economic-friendly material with high strength and anti-corrosion characteristics; as the base of the anode. The thickness of the coating was 1 μm; and both sides of the base were plated with the platinum. Sample with two different materials of anode was referred as A1 (stainless steel mesh) and A2 (platinum-plated titanium mesh); respectively. The applied exterior power was 17 V cm −1 in both conditions. And the layout of cathode inside the sample box was set as L1; which was to be described in the next chapter. 3.2 Results As shown in Fig. 3 a; it was noticed that after first 3 h of the test; serious electrode corrosion was observed on the stainless steel mesh electrode. The corrosion is caused by water electrolytic reaction; which means Fe (the main element of the anode) was transformed into Fe 3+ constantly and dissolved into water during the EO regeneration. However; the platinum-plated titanium mesh was insoluble and steady in the electrolytic reaction throughout the test with a total time beyond 120 h; as shown in Fig. 3 b. And no visible change was found on the surface of anode; and a longer operation-time could be predicted. The experimental results of sample A1 and A2; including the time of Phase 1 and 2; peak and initial current; were shown in Table 2 . Phase 1 refers to the process of the EO regeneration impacted by the serious Joule effect; which should be shortened. And Phase 2 is proofed to be the most effective period in the EO regeneration and should be lengthened as long as possible. The detailed description of Phase 1 and 2 are referred in literature [11] . As shown in the Fig. 4 ; the m weg and current of the first 4 h in the experiment presented large difference between sample A1 and A2. From Table 2 and Fig. 4 ; it is noticed that the initial current of A2 was evidently lower than that of A1; especially in the first half hour. Although the m weg of A2 was not as high as that of A1 in first few minutes; the shorter time period of Phase 1 of A2 could make up the difference. And then the m weg of A2 kept ahead during the experiment. It is clear that the performance of EO regeneration was highly improved by the application of the platinum-plated titanium anode. First; because of the reversible reaction of this anode (Pt + 2OH − ⇔ Pt(OH) 2 + 2e − ) in the EO regeneration; the anode could not be corroded. So the work lifetime of the system (the time of Phase 2) was considerably increased from around 6 h to over 120 h. And no visible changes were found on the surface of anode. The corrosion was considered to have a serious negative effect to the performance of the EO regeneration for three reasons. (a) The anode was corroded rapidly during the regeneration process and the area was reduced; which would seriously reduce the water removal rate. (b) It could cause the insoluble substance deposit into the material; which led to the increase of resistance and the decrease of current. (c) When the anode was wholly corroded; the EO regeneration would stop. So the platinum-plated titanium anode significantly enhanced the practical application potential of the new regeneration method. Moreover; the use of titanium anode; which was made of inert metal with low electric conductivity; effectively reduced the initial current and the Joule heating effect. (The serious Joule heat effect caused by high initial current; which happened in the application of ordinary anode; not only led to the stagnation of EO regeneration of 2–3 h (Phase 1); but also added extra cooling load to the air-conditioning system.) As shown in Table 2 ; at the beginning process of the regeneration; compared to the corroded anode; the peak and mean initial current of using platinum-plated titanium anode reduced around 80%. 4 Layout of cathode 4.1 Methodology In the previous experiment; it was found that a thin drenched layer (filter cloth) under the cathode had a significant influence on the water removal rate m we ∗ ) of the EO regeneration [11] . And different layouts between the layer and cathode may have different effects to the regeneration rate. So we designed four kinds of layout; with the different relative position between the cathode and filter cloth inside the sample box; to investigate the detail effect of the drenched layer. As shown in the Table 3 ; the layout was named L1; L2; L3 and L4; respectively. During the test; the applied electric strength was 17 V cm −1 in all conditions. And the anode was the platinum-plated titanium mesh. 4.2 Results The EO regeneration rates with four different layouts in Phase 2 were shown in Table 4 . To make the result more accurate; we repeated the experiment four times with every layout inside the sample box. From the results; it is clear that when the sample was fitted with the cathode only (L3); the EO regeneration rate was quite low. If a layer of filter cloth was added under the cathode; the regeneration rate increased; even without any measures (L2). As the trestle was used to keep the contact area between the cathode and the filter cloth as large as possible (L1); the average regeneration rate conspicuously increased. However; if the layer of filter cloth was placed upon the cathode (L4; the filter cloth was fitted between the desiccant and cathode); the water removal quantity by gravity only was superior than the water removal quantity by both gravity and EO forces; which means the EO regeneration rate became negative in this condition. The possible reason of the results might be that the influences on the flow pattern inside the micro-channels of desiccant varied from these four kinds of layout. In 2006; Buhai et al. [14] published that different flow patterns between open and close electrodes in the micro-channels and their influences. As shown in Fig. 5 a; the simulation results show that the impermeable electrodes lead to a cyclic flow pattern inside the pore of the desiccant; which makes the whole flow rate weaken significantly. However; it is contrast to the system with permeable electrodes represented by Fig. 5 b. In our experiment; the cathode with a layer of filter cloth above was similar to the first one; in which the cyclic flow pattern caused the reduction of water removal quantity by both forces. In contrast; when the filter cloth was placed under the cathode with a trestle; the sample box system was more similar to the second one because of the water absorption effect of cloth. So the flow direction was almost from the anode to cathode; which means that the EO regeneration could have a better performance in this condition. And the level of the flow pattern approaching to the ideal one increases as the increase of the contact area between the cathode and the filter cloth. So the use of trestle could result in higher performance of the regeneration system. 5 Interrupted power 5.1 Methodology In EO soil concretion; it has been proved that interrupted power can remove more water than continuous power in electro-osmotic dewatering by Robie in 1994 [15] ; and then Gopalakrishnan et al. found that there was an optimal off-time which yields maximum water removal in 1996 [16] . However; there is no experimental investigation to validate whether the measure could enhance the EO regeneration rate or not; and to find out the optimal on/off-time in the specified electric field strength. Based on this consideration; we tested the EO regeneration with the interrupted power supply; by the time-delay relay which could periodically interrupt the power and simultaneously short-circuited the electrodes. To find out the optimal parameter of the method; we fixed the on-time (time of connection) at 30 s; and change the off-time (time of interruption) from 0.1 s to 2 s. Besides; according to the results above; we applied the platinum-plated titanium anode and laid the sample box as layout L1. 5.2 Results The enhanced percentage of EO regeneration rate; which means the ratio between m we ∗ gained with and without the time-delay relay; was shown in Fig. 6 . As shown in the results; the interrupted power generated by the relay significantly enhanced the regeneration rate up to 1.5 times; comparing with the condition without it. The energy-saving potential could also be improved; consequently. The main reasons were: (a) Because of the electrolytic reaction; H + was generated on the anode and OH − was generated on the cathode persistently. Then these ions assembled at the opposite electrode with the water flow and caused the decrease of the effective electric field. The interrupted power resists the reduction by neutralizing the positive and negative ions in electrodes during the off-time; (b) In the conventional EO regeneration; the Zeta potential near the anode decreases because of the pH decrease [17] caused by the electrolytic reaction; which reduces the EO regeneration rate. The interrupted power reverses the electrode reaction on the anode and thus the pH near the anode increases during the off-time. However; during the off-time; the electric field inside the desiccant was opposite; which caused the reversed water flow. As a result; if the off-time was set too long; the EO regeneration rate would decrease. So an optimal ratio between the on and off-time should be investigated to present the better enhancing effect. As shown in the Fig. 6 ; the optimal on/off-time was found at 30 s:1.3 s with the applied electric field strength at 17 V cm −1 ; and the optimal on/off-time was 30 s:0.8 s with the applied electric field strength at 11 V cm −1 . Based on our previous research [1] ; to compare with other regeneration methods; the energy consumption is represented by the energy consumption rate. The rate is defined as the ratio of the energy consumed and the moisture mass removed. As shown in Table 5 ; the energy consumption rate of the EO regeneration was relative lower than several other methods. If the improvements (changing layout of cathode and introducing in the interrupted power) are applied properly in the EO regeneration system; the regeneration rate will increase and the consumption rate will be further reduced to 1.0 × 10 3 kJ kg −1 . It is proved that the improved EO regeneration system has higher energy-saving potential. 6 Electric field strength 6.1 Methodology In the conventional electro-osmosis theory; the EO flow rate was verified to vary directly with the electric field strength. For instance; Yao et al. found that increasing the electric field strength would linearly raise the maximum flow rate of EO pump in 2003 [18] . However; whether the relationship is correct in the EO regeneration system needs further verification. In this test; we changed the applied electric strength from 0 to 20 V cm −1 by a tunable DC power. For the better performance of the system; we applied the platinum-plated titanium anode and layout L1 in the test. The time-delay relay was not included in the circle because of the changing of electric field strength. 6.2 Results As shown in the Fig. 7 ; it is clear that the EO regeneration rate was not proportional to the electric field strength. The main reason was the mismatch of the adsorption and regeneration (desorption) of the desiccant. As shown in the Fig. 8 ; when the electric field strength was raised; the temperature of desiccant increased accordingly because of the more serious Joule heat effect. Higher temperature not only significantly impacted the adsorption ability of the artificial zeolite [18] ; but also improved the evaporation of the water inside. Because of the evaporation and reduction of adsorption; the porosity of the desiccant decreased rapidly; which caused the serious decrease of EO regeneration rate [19] . As shown in Fig. 7 ; when the applied field strength was adjusted at 8.5–13 V cm −1 ; the m we ∗ was superior compared to other conditions; which means that the most suitable value of electric field strength ranges from 8.5 to 13 V cm −1 for our EO regeneration system. It was verified that it is possible to obtain higher regeneration rate in EO regeneration system by applying the optimal electric field strength. However; it should be noticed that the optimal value varies with the type of desiccant; the structure of system; the operation parameters and environment and so on. 7 Summary In this essay; we experimented and analyzed four measures to enhance the performance of the EO regeneration system. From the results; several conclusions are listed as follow: (a) The use of platinum-plated titanium mesh anode improved the work lifetime of the system from 6 h to over 120 h; and effectively reduced the initial current and the Joule heating effect. (b) Application of a layer of filter cloth closely under the cathode with a trestle could significantly enhance the EO regeneration rate up to 0.0021 g s −1 . Besides; putting the filter cloth between the desiccant and cathode made the EO regeneration rate negative because of the cyclic flow inside the desiccant. (c) The interrupted power enhanced the regeneration rate up to 1.5 times compared with the condition without it. And the optimal on–off-time was found at 30 s:1.3 s with 17 V cm −1 and 30 s:0.8 s with 11 V cm −1 . (d) Because of the mismatch of adsorption and regeneration characteristics of desiccant; the most suitable value of electric field strength ranges from 8.5 to 13 V cm −1 in our EO regeneration system. The improvement of the EO regeneration performance improves the potential of practical use and energy-saving. The further work includes investigating whether the improved EO regeneration system could work under the ordinary summer outdoor environment and finding the influencing factors of it. 2h4fUiat.title: A novel optimization sizing model for hybrid solar-wind power generation system
2h4fUiat.abstract: This paper develops the Hybrid Solar-Wind System Optimization Sizing (HSWSO) model, to optimize the capacity sizes of different components of hybrid solar-wind power generation systems employing a battery bank. The HSWSO model consists of three parts: the model of the hybrid system, the model of Loss of Power Supply Probability (LPSP) and the model of the Levelised Cost of Energy (LCE). The flow chart of the HSWSO model is also illustrated. With the incorporated HSWSO model, the sizing optimization of hybrid solar-wind power generation systems can be achieved technically and economically according to the system reliability requirements. A case study is reported to show the importance of the HSWSO model for sizing the capacities of wind turbines, PV panel and battery banks of a hybrid solar-wind renewable energy system.

ZsScoqMf.title: Optimal sizing method for stand-alone hybrid solar–wind system with LPSP technology by using genetic algorithm
ZsScoqMf.abstract: System power reliability under varying weather conditions and the corresponding system cost are the two main concerns for designing hybrid solar–wind power generation systems. This paper recommends an optimal sizing method to optimize the configurations of a hybrid solar–wind system employing battery banks. Based on a genetic algorithm (GA), which has the ability to attain the global optimum with relative computational simplicity, one optimal sizing method was developed to calculate the optimum system configuration that can achieve the customers required loss of power supply probability (LPSP) with a minimum annualized cost of system (ACS). The decision variables included in the optimization process are the PV module number, wind turbine number, battery number, PV module slope angle and wind turbine installation height. The proposed method has been applied to the analysis of a hybrid system which supplies power for a telecommunication relay station, and good optimization performance has been found. Furthermore, the relationships between system power reliability and system configurations were also given.

L1G7WmA5.title: Investigation on heat transfer around buried coils of pile foundation heat exchangers for ground-coupled heat pump applications
L1G7WmA5.abstract: The application of ground heat exchangers (GHEs) has attracted much attention for its advantages in terms of energy-saving and emission-reduction. Therefore, it is significant to introduce heat transfer into investigation, the paper illustrated the existing heat transfer models in order to analyze the GHEs with buried coils. Line heat source, cylindrical heat source and ring-coil heat source are introduced step by step. For the present, the borehole GHEs are the mainstream, and in recent years pile foundation GHEs have been followed with interest on account of heat transfer superiority as well as lowering initial cost and saving land area. Concerning that groundwater flow exist in geological stratum sometimes, so that the thermal analysis about heat transfer should be composed of two cases, i.e. models under the condition of both pure conduction and combination that include conduction and advection. It is obvious that ring-coil model is on the verge of actual situation for pile foundation GHEs with buried coils from the academic research perspectives, nevertheless for some engineering computation problems which the result error can be permitted in the certain range, other heat transfer models can be chosen in order to simplify the calculation process. © 2012 Elsevier Ltd. All rights reserved.

N2tv9GbE.title: The analysis on solid cylindrical heat source model of foundation pile ground heat exchangers with groundwater flow
N2tv9GbE.abstract: This paper presents a solid cylindrical simulation model of heat transfer around foundation pile ground heat exchangers with groundwater flow for ground-coupled heat pump (GCHP) applications. The analytical solutions of the temperature response in the heat transfer process including heat conduction and convection were obtained. The impact of groundwater flow on the heat transfer has been investigated. The heat transfer processes with and without groundwater flow were compared. It was found thatgroundwater flow has a considerable effect on the heat transfer process, especially when the groundwater flow velocity attains a certain order of magnitude. If the system is designed reasonably and groundwater temperature is below a certain range, groundwater flow is favorable to the heat transfer between the foundation pile ground heat exchangers (GHEs) and surrounding ground medium, and can improve the energy performance of the heating and cooling system of the ground-coupled heat pump for energy conservation of buildings. © 2013 Elsevier Ltd.

37uJhujP.title: Current status of research on optimum sizing of stand-alone hybrid solar–wind power generation systems
37uJhujP.abstract: Solar and wind energy systems are omnipresent, freely available, environmental friendly, and they are considered as promising power generating sources due to their availability and topological advantages for local power generations. Hybrid solar–wind energy systems, uses two renewable energy sources, allow improving the system efficiency and power reliability and reduce the energy storage requirements for stand-alone applications. The hybrid solar–wind systems are becoming popular in remote area power generation applications due to advancements in renewable energy technologies and substantial rise in prices of petroleum products. This paper is to review the current state of the simulation, optimization and control technologies for the stand-alone hybrid solar–wind energy systems with battery storage. It is found that continued research and development effort in this area is still needed for improving the systems’ performance, establishing techniques for accurately predicting their output and reliably integrating them with other renewable or conventional power generation sources.

ObGnf2Q5.title: Energy and economic performance analysis of an open cycle solar desiccant dehumidification air-conditioning system for application in Hong Kong
ObGnf2Q5.abstract: In this article, a transient simulation model and the EnergyPlus were used to study the energy performance and economical feasibility for integrating a solar liquid desiccant dehumidification system with a conventional vapor compression air-conditioning system for the weather condition of Hong Kong. The vapor compression system capacity in the solar assisted air-conditioning system can be reduced to 19 kW from original 28 kW of a conventional air-conditioning system as a case study due to the solar desiccant cooling. The economical performance of the solar desiccant dehumidification system is compared with that of the conventional air-conditioning system. The results show that the energy saving potentials due to incorporation of the solar desiccant dehumidification system in a traditional air-conditioning system is significant for the hot wet weather in Hong Kong due to higher COP resulted from higher supply chilled water temperature from chiller plants. The annual operation energy savings for the hybrid system is 6760 kWh and the payback period of the hybrid system is around 7 years. The study shows that the solar assisted air-conditioning is a viable technology for utilizations in subtropical areas. The feasibility of using desiccant dehumidification has been studied by Davangere et al. (1999a,b), Mateus and Oliveira (2009) and Kaushik et al. (1991) . The annual energy performance and energy saving potentials of using liquid desiccant were reported by Nesreen et al. (2003), Liu et al. (2006), Khalid et al. (1997), Ghali (2008), Yadav (1995), Dai et al. (2001) and Yang and Yan (1992) . Certain performance enhancement measures that affect the system performance (such as energy storage and heat recovery) have also been investigated by Oliveti et al. (2000) and Zhang (2006) . Solar radiation is mainly used as energy source, which is collected by common solar collectors, to re-concentrate the dilute desiccant solution. The open cycle solar collector, on the other hand, utilizes not only the solar energy but also the unsaturated air as regeneration energy source. It is possible to make humid area, like Hong Kong, to use solar desiccant dehumidification system. However, not much work has been done to investigate the performance of the liquid desiccant dehumidification/regeneration air-conditioning system with open cycle solar C/R. In this paper, the transient performance of the solar liquid desiccant dehumidification/regeneration air-conditioning system and a vapor compression air-conditioning system is studied using synoptically generated weather data of Hong Kong. The solar liquid desiccant system of the present study replaces a 28.8 kW vapor compression unit for a typical office in Hong Kong characterized by a high ventilation rate and high latent load. Based on the hourly simulation studies for a wide range of recorded ambient conditions of Hong Kong, this program can predict the annual energy consumption of the solar liquid desiccant air-conditioning system in comparison with the conventional vapor compression system which is simulated using the EnergyPlus for the entire A/C season. An economical analysis is performed for the integrated solar desiccant air-conditioning system compared with the conventional vapor compression system. 2 Problem formulation 2.1 Local weather data For applications requiring prediction of annual performance and design of energy systems, there are two kinds of annual weather data in general use in Hong Kong, one is the typical meteorological year (TMY) developed by Chan et al. (2006) and another is the example weather year or test reference year (TRY) developed by Wong and Ngan (1993) . Both of these two kinds of weather data consider the weighting factor of the annual and monthly mean values of major weather indices, and the month with the smallest deviation from the mean value is taken as ‘standard’ month or ‘typical’ year. Selection of the TMY or TRY highly relays on the weighting factors of the different metrological variables. For strict statistical significance, different energy systems will have different TMYs or TRYs. The aforementioned weather data are mostly for building energy simulation and may not be appropriate to address the renewable energy application systems such as the open cycle solar desiccant dehumidification air-conditioning system. In this study, a new series of weather data which were generated by the first order multivariate Markov chain model were used to drive the simulation model. This new weather data is based on 15 years of actual hourly weather data of Hong Kong and dose not relay on the weighting factors, which makes it suitable for simulating the energy systems with more than one dominant weather variables. Fig. 1 shows one set of simulated weather data. The statistical characteristics of the generated weather are compared with the long-term average value of the real weather data, TMY and TRY. The comparison includes annual average value, standard deviation, yearly maximum value and minimum value. The results reveal that the simulated weather data well preserved the characteristics of the real weather data and the relative errors are all within 5% magnitude. In order to ensure that the traditional vapor compression air-conditioning system and the solar desiccant air-conditioning system are evaluated by the same stick-yard, the new weather data was converted to an EPW file which can be read by the EnergyPlus in the building energy simulation process. 2.2 Building energy simulation using EnergyPlus The objective of the work is to compare the energy performance between the hybrid desiccant air-conditioning system and the conventional air-conditioning system for a high latent load application in a subtropical area like Hong Kong. The selected building is a 130 m 2 office building located on the first floor of a building characterized by a ‘L’ shape. The building is oriented due north. A single glazing window of 3 mm is installed on south wall. The window to wall area ratio is approximately 0.07. The walls consist of 2.5 cm stucco over 10 cm common brick and gypboard. The roof is a built up roof with 1.5 cm stone above 1 cm felt over 2.5 cm dense insulation supported by 5 cm heavy weight concrete. The shape and orientation of the building are shown in Fig. 2 . The length of the office is 10 m and its width and height are 5 m and 3 m, respectively. The heat transfer coefficients ( U -value) are 0.4 W/(m 2 °C) for roof, 3 W/(m 2 °C) for wall, 2.19 W/(m 2 °C) for partition, 1.03 W/(m 2 °C) for floor, and 6.17 W/(m 2 °C) for windows. The internal lighting heat gain is set at 2343 W and the equipment heat gain is taken as 7322 W. It is assumed that 10 occupants are working in the building. To evaluate the dehumidification ability of the solar desiccant air-conditioning system, the moisture gain from the occupant and the fresh air flow rate are both set at the maximum value, i.e. 0.4 kg/(h person) and 133 m 3 /(h person), respectively. The indoor design conditions are 24 °C of dry bulb air temperature and 55% of relative humidity. The cooling load of the space was calculated on an hourly basis using the EnergyPlus. The sensible and latent loads required for maintaining the building at the specified indoor conditions of temperature and humidity are calculated for the conventional VAV system design. The peak cooling load is 28.8 kW, consisting of a sensible part of 22.8 kW and a latent part of 6.0 kW. The monthly cooling energy consumption is also evaluated by the EnergyPlus, as presented in Fig. 3 . The results reveal that in a subtropical area like Hong Kong, cooling provision is almost needed throughout the whole year. This may explain why the energy consumption of air conditioning is the dominant building energy consumption which is around 40–70% of the total annual energy consumption of a commercial building. Fig. 3 also shows that during the summer seasons from May to September the latent cooling load is more than 40% of the total cooling load. The high percentage of latent cooling load in summer, which is the character of the building cooling load profile in this area, makes it hard for the conventional vapor compression air-conditioning system to accurately control the temperature and humidity simultaneously. The energy consumption for removing the water vapor in air is significant. 2.3 Solar desiccant air-conditioning system 2.3.1 System configuration Fig. 4 shows a schematic diagram of a solar desiccant air-conditioning system. Ambient humid air enters the supply air duct and passes through the packed type dehumidifier of the primary air handling unit where it will be dehumidified and heated by dry desiccant. After exiting from the primary air handling unit, the hot and dry air is then cooled by a cooling coil and then distributed to the room. The liquid desiccant solution is regenerated in the solar C/R. In this study, the inlet temperature of the diluted desiccant solution is set at the equilibrium temperature to balance the solar C/R’s performance and the auxiliary energy consumption. The total heat energy required to regenerate the desiccant solution is partly supplied by the solar energy and the rest is supplied by an electrical auxiliary heater. To increase the diluted solution temperature, the desiccant solution from the dehumidifier passes through the heat exchanger and is heated by the hot desiccant solution leaving the solar C/R. If the solar radiation is not good and the solution temperature is still lower than the equilibrium temperature after passing through the heat exchanger, an auxiliary heater is used to heat the diluted desiccant solution to the desired temperature. An auxiliary heat source can be used to increase the temperature, e.g. by natural gas or electricity. In this study, electricity is used. 2.3.2 Simulation of system component – the solar C/R A brief description of the governing equations of each component in the system is provided in the following sections. A simplified simulation model has been developed by the author to predict the performance of the solar C/R. As the concentration of the desiccant solution change can be assumed to be negligible compared with the solution temperature over a short distance, the equilibrium humidity ratio of the desiccant solution can be considered to be the function of the solution temperature. Thus, the basic energy and mass balances of the solar C/R can be described by linear and non-homogeneous relationships: (1) d ( Δ T ) dNTU = - C ∗ + 1 1 + Y a , avg · R cv Δ T + C ∗ Le Δ Y + 1 h · λ ∗ C ∗ ( I · α · τ g - Q rad ) + Q con 1 + Y a , avg · R cv (2) d ( Δ Y ) dNTU = S T · λ ∗ · C ∗ Δ T - 1 Le ( 1 + S T · λ ∗ · C ∗ ) Δ Y - S T · C ∗ h ( I · α · τ g - Q rad ) where S T and λ ∗ are approximated as constants with narrow range of operating conditions for the regeneration processes; h is the convective heat transfer coefficient (kW/m 2 K); I represents the global solar irradiation on the collector area, (W/m 2 ); Le is the Lewis factor for the overall heat and mass transfer processes; Q con is the heat loss from the glazing cover to environment, (W/m 2 ); Q rad stands for radiation heat transfer from the solution film to the glass cover, (W/m 2 ); NTU is the number of heat transfer units; Δ T and Δ Y are the dimensionless variables which represent the driving force of heat and mass transfer between the desiccant solution and air. These two variables are defined as follows: (3) Δ T = ( T s - T a ) / λ ∗ and Δ Y = Y a - Y el Assuming that the coefficients in Eqs. (1) and (2) can all be approximated as constants, Eqs. (1) and (2) can be deemed as linear and non-homogeneous. (4) are as follows: (6) k 1 = λ 1 - a 11 a 12 and k 2 = λ 2 - a 11 a 12 For the given initial conditions, the following equations for constants C 1 and C 2 can be obtained: (7) C 1 = Δ T i k 2 - Δ Y i - k 2 D 1 + D 2 ( k 2 - k 1 ) e λ 1 · NTU i and C 2 = - Δ T i k 1 + Δ Y i + k 1 D 1 - D 2 ( k 2 - k 1 ) e λ 2 · NTU i The above equations describe the air regeneration process in the solar C/R using liquid desiccant solution. Eq. (4) gives the driving potential of the heat and mass transfer, and the air outlet temperature, humidity ratio and solution outlet temperature of the control volume can be resolved. The first two parts of the RHS of Eq. (4) describe the heat and mass transfer phenomenon; the last part of the RHS of Eq. (4) represents the effect of climate conditions, especially solar radiation and ambient temperature. With this equation we can predict the outlet conditions of air temperature, humidity ratio and solution temperature. In order to use this analytical solution with confidence for predicting the outlet condition of the desiccant solution and amount of water evaporation, validation is needed. The accuracy is examined by the experiment outcome. Experiments were conducted in a lab-scale open cycle solar C/R. The experimental setup consists of solar collector/regenerator, fans, electrical heater, solution tanks, pumps, flow regulator/indicator, PID controller and data acquisition devices. The rectangular solar C/R dimensions are 2200 mm × 1200 mm with 100 mm air channel between the glass cover and blackened absorption plate. Lithium bromide–water is chosen to be the working fluid. During the experiment, the inlet temperature, flow rate and concentration of the desiccant solution is controlled between 35–40 °C, 14.16–21.24 kg/h m (about 200–300 ccm/min), and 20–25% respectively. It should be point out that the air flow velocity decreases quickly after first 0.5 m. The air flow at the end part of the solar C/R is as low as 0.3 m/s and in this case, the effect of nature convection cannot be neglected. It is necessary to involve Grashof number in the correlation equation to calculate the local Nusselt number and use measured air velocity profile to modify the initial assumed uniform air velocity. The results are shown in Fig. 5 with the predicted values of the analytical model. For both case, the temperature and humidity profiles are well preserved in the simplified model and the relative errors, which are defined as the difference of the simplified model and experimental values at different measure points divided by the experimental values, of air temperature, humidity ratio and solution temperature are less than 10%. The maximum difference happens in the rear part of the solar C/R where is mostly influenced by the fluctuation of ambient condition. 2.3.3 Simulation of the dehumidifier For annual performance study, the empirical correlations developed by Chung (1994) were adopted. The air and liquid flow rates, air and liquid inlet temperatures, column and packing dimensions, and the equilibrium properties of the desiccant solutions are involved in this model. The column efficiency for a given packing height flow rate geometry and liquid desiccant can be expressed as: (8) ε = 1 - 0.205 G in L in 0.174 exp 0.985 t G in t L in ( aZ ) 0.184 X 1.68 1 - 0.152 exp - 0.686 t G in t L in X 3.388 where X is defined as the fraction of the vapor pressure depression of the desiccant solution to the vapor pressure of pure water, ( P water − P solution )/ P water . In Eq. (8) , a is the heat and mass transfer area to volume ratio, m 2 /m 3 , and Z is the packing height, m. 2.3.4 Modelling of the heat exchanger Since the flow rates of the inlet diluted desiccant solution and the outlet hot concentrated desiccant solution are almost equal, and if their specific heats are assumed the same and the effectiveness of the heat exchanger can be written as follows: (9) ε ex = T in - T in ′ T in - T out 2.3.5 Modelling of the solution in the tank The desiccant solution in the solution tank is assumed to be well mixed and no concentration gradient exists in the solution tank. As the collected solar energy is stored in the form of chemical energy, the heat loss of the solution to the environment is set to zero and the temperature of the solution is equal to the ambient air temperature for all the time. 2.3.6 Modelling of the vapor compression subsystem The cooling load and the chiller power consumption of the vapor compression subsystem are different from those of the conventional air-conditioning system in two ways: firstly, the internal latent load and the latent fresh air load are all treated by the liquid desiccant solution. The chilled water only needs to meet the requirement of the sensible part of the cooling load; secondly, the sensible part of the cooling load can be handled by higher temperature chilled water. Increase of the chilled water temperature can significantly improve the energy performance of the chiller. To simplify the analysis process and to focus on the desiccant dehumidification system, the improvement of the chiller for increasing the chilled water temperature is estimated from the efficiency of an equivalent ideal Carnot refrigeration cycle. For a conventional air-conditioning system, the condensation temperature and evaporation temperature are assumed as 40 °C and 2 °C, respectively, and the COP of the chiller is assumed to be 3.5 as the chilled water of 15 °C can be used to remove the sensible heat in the processed air, the condensation temperature and evaporation temperature of the chiller in the solar desiccant air-conditioning system is assumed to be 40 °C and 13 °C. The corresponding ideal efficiency of the chiller in the solar desiccant air-conditioning system is calculated to be 10.6. Considering the validity of a real chiller, 40% of the energy efficiency’s improvement can be expected. For the conventional vapor compression system, the average COP of the chiller is calculated to be 3.3 by the simulation software EnergyPlus. Thus, the average COP of the chiller in the solar desiccant air-conditioning system is estimated to be 4.62. The load of the vapor compression subsystem is calculated by: (10) Q C , C / R = Q C - M pa ( h a , out - h a , in ) where Q C is the total cooling load of the conventional vapor compression system, kW. h a , in is the enthalpy of the ambient air and h a , out is the enthalpy of the air leaving the dehumidifier, kJ/(kg K). M pa is the mass flow rate of the primary air, kg/(s m). The hourly cooling load is calculated by the EnergyPlus over the whole cooling season. In addition, the solar desiccant dehumidification/regeneration model is used to obtain the hourly condition of the process air leaving the dehumidifier during the cooling season. The hourly enthalpy, h a , out , is easily determined and thus the hourly load of the vapor compression subsystem can be determined over the whole cooling months. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Annual energy performance of the solar desiccant air-conditioning system In the solar desiccant air-conditioning system, the latent load is handled by the desiccant solution and the sensible load is mainly taken by the higher temperature chilled water. The electricity consumption of the chillers can be greatly reduced. Fig. 6 compares the monthly average power consumption of the chillers for these two air-conditioning systems. By introducing the solar desiccant dehumidification subsystem into the air-conditioning system, the chiller power consumption is reduced, especially during summer season when ambient air is very humid and the latent load accounts for a bigger share of the total cooling load. It is quite safe to replace the 28.8 kW (8.0 TR) chiller with a smaller 19 kW (5.0 TR) chiller due to the reduced latent cooling load. The total system energy saving potential cannot be determined just from the electric power consumption of the chillers. The energy performance of the solar desiccant dehumidification subsystem is needed in the evaluation of the total system performance. As the lowest inlet temperature of the desiccant solution is set at the equilibrium temperature with respect to the partial vapor pressure of ambient air, auxiliary energy is needed in those cloudy days when the outlet desiccant solution temperature is not high enough to heat the desiccant solution to the desired temperature. Fig. 7 illustrates the auxiliary energy consumption of the solar desiccant air-conditioning system. The area of the solar C/R is designed to be 24 m 2 and the solution tank capacity is 5 m 3 . It can be seen that the auxiliary power is mainly needed from June to October. Although solar radiation during these months is abundant, the air humidity ratio is also higher than that in other months. Higher humidity ratio requires higher inlet solution temperature. Further more, auxiliary power is mainly needed in early morning and late afternoon when solar radiation is comparatively lower. Generally, the outlet desiccant solution temperature is higher enough and can heat the inlet desiccant solution to the equilibrium temperature in a day. Most part of the heating energy is provided by the energy recovery heat exchanger and the consumption of the auxiliary energy is reasonable. For the solar collector/regeneration system, it is very important to balance the dehumidification task and the amount of water evaporation of the solar C/R to ensure continuous operation. Fig. 8 shows the hourly dehumidification capacity and water evaporation rate of a 32 m 2 solar C/R and 1 m 3 solution tank system. The annual dehumidification capacity and water evaporation rate of the 32 m 2 solar C/R are almost equal, i.e. 2.5 × 10 4 kg. Although the annual dehumidification task and water evaporation are balanced, mismatches between these two values still exist on monthly and daily basis. As the ambient condition fluctuates with unsteady characteristics, storage tanks are often needed in the soar desiccant air-conditioning system to ensure continuous operation of the whole system. The desiccant solution is suitable for energy storage. The energy storage capacity in liquid desiccants such as aqueous solutions of hygroscopic salts is up to 3.5 times higher than solid desiccants such as zeolites or silica gel (related to the same dehumidification process) ( Kaushik et al., 1991 ). In this study, the upper and lower limits of the desiccant solution are set at 50% and 25%, respectively. When the desiccant solution concentration is higher than 50%, the desiccant solution regeneration stops to avoid crystallization of the hygroscopic salts. When the solution concentration is lower than 25%, its ability to absorb moisture from air is too low to operate the dehumidification cycle effectively. Fig. 9 shows the effect of the solution tank capacity on the solution concentration. 3.2 Economic analysis To demonstrate the feasibility of this solar energy system, an economic feasibility analysis of the solar desiccant system has been made. The solar desiccant system is cost effective when its extra cost is less than the present value of the energy savings. The cost of the vapor compression system for the office with cooling load of 28 kW is about HK$20,000. When the desiccant system is integrated with a traditional A/C system, the desiccant dehumidifier can reduce the size of the vapor compression system to 19 kW and the cost of the chiller can be reduced to about HK$12,500. The open cycle solar C/R is not a market available product at present. As the structure of the open cycle solar C/R is almost the same as a flat panel solar hot water collector, the cost of the open cycle solar cycle can be estimated according to the price of a solar water heater, which can be estimated as HK$2000/m 2 . Installation cost is assumed to be included in this item as well. Other detailed component costs are listed in Table 1 . The total initial cost of the conventional vapor compression air-conditioning system is HK$79,040. For the solar desiccant dehumidification cycle, the initial cost varies according to the capacity of the solution tanks and area of the solar C/R. In Table 1 , two sets of the solar C/R area and solution tank capacity combinations are listed. Both of these two system configurations can ensure 99% reliability throughout the whole year. The following performance and operating cost analysis is mainly based on the second configuration which has lower initial investment. Fig. 10 shows the monthly energy savings when compared with the conventional vapor compression air-conditioning system. The monthly peak energy consumption is 2400 kWh in August. The annual air-conditioning energy index for the vapor compression system, which is defined as the annual energy consumption of the air-conditioning system divided by the total floor area, is 114.45 kWh/m 2 . When introducing the solar desiccant dehumidification system into the air-conditioning system, the energy index can be reduced to 52.09 kWh/m 2 . The advantage of the solar desiccant dehumidification system is more clearly revealed in Fig. 11 . The maximum relative energy saving is 59.65% in August. A higher portion of latent load in the total ventilation load leads to more energy saving. The simulation also reveals that the relative energy saving follows the trend of the latent load. For our case, the relative energy saving reaches its peak value from June to September, which are characterized as highly humid seasons. In other months, the relative energy saving is comparatively low, especially in March and November. The proposed liquid desiccant dehumidification system performs better in a highly humid climate. The operating energy cost of the integrated system over the whole cooling season is given by: (11) COST = ( E elec , chiller + E elec , pump + Q aux ) C e where E elec is the annual electric energy consumption of the chiller, pumps and fans in kWh and Q aux is the annual energy consumption of the electric heater in kWh. C e is the electricity price in HK$/kWh. In Hong Kong, the electric energy cost is around 0.9–1.17 HK$/kWh. In this study, 1 HK$/kWh is used. The life cycle savings (LCS) is the difference between the present value of the energy savings over the life cycle resulting from the use of the solar desiccant dehumidifier and the extra initial investment. If the result is positive, the desiccant system is worthy of the extra expenditure. A market discount rate of 8% and an inflation rate of 5% are used in the calculations. The life cycle of 20 years is considered for the two systems. For a set of specified economic parameters, the return on investment (ROI) can be determined. A positive LCS implies that the ROI is greater than the market discount rate. In this study, an initial extra expenditure C is needed at a market discount rate d of 0.08, in order to make a saving S in the yearly energy bill that is inflated at a rate e , 0.05 over a period N of 20 years. The system is assumed to have no resale value. The life cycle savings is then given by Duffie and Beckman (1980) : (12) LCS = - C + PWF ( N , e , d ) S where (13) PWF ( N , e , d ) = 1 d - e 1 - 1 + e 1 + d N if e ≠ d (14) PWF ( N , e , d ) = N 1 + d if e = d As the area of the solar C/R increases from 20 m 2 to 36 m 2 shown in Fig. 12 , the LCS decreases linearly from HK$81,787 to HK$54,140, while the system reliability, which is defined as the ratio of the number of hours that can meet the dehumidification task and the total number of hours that need dehumidification, quickly increases from 85% to 100%. As the area of the solar C/R was fixed at 24 m 2 , the effect of the desiccant solution tank capacity on the LCS and the reliability was investigated. The results are illustrated in Fig. 13 . Generally speaking, the solution tank capacity and the area of solar C/R have the same effect on the LCS and reliability. As the price of the solution tank is cheaper than that of the solar C/R, increase of the solution tank capacity seems more economical. If these two system configurations (32/24 m 2 solar C/R and 1/5 m 3 solution tank) are compared, they have almost the same reliability of 99%, but the LCSs are quite different. For the system with large solar C/R area and smaller solution tank capacity, the LCS is HK$60,805, while for the system of smaller solar C/R area and larger solution tank the value is HK$70,119. Thus, increasing the solution capacity might be a better method to obtain higher system reliability. Fig. 14 shows the variation of the life cycle savings in the life cycle period. The payback period of the larger solution tank and smaller solar C/R area combination is almost 7 years, while the pay back period for the larger solar C/R area and smaller solution tank is a little more than 8 years. The payback period of the solar liquid desiccant air-conditioning system is a little longer than that of the common solar hot water system which is around 3–5 years, but much shorter than the payback period of solar photovoltaic systems. The economic feasibility of the solar desiccant air-conditioning system can be further improved by replacing the auxiliary electric heater with a gas boiler. 4 Conclusions In this article, a transient simulation model has been developed for the solar liquid desiccant dehumidification system. Together with the EnergyPlus, the model was used to study the energy performance and economic feasibility of a solar liquid desiccant dehumidification system integrated with a conventional vapor compression air-conditioning system for the weather conditions of Hong Kong. To increase the economic practicality of such a solar assisted air-conditioning system, the combined system utilizes solar energy and unsaturated ambient air for regenerating liquid desiccant solution. Besides, a simplified heat and mass transfer simulation model of the solar C/Rs is developed to study the hourly performance of the hybrid system for a case study. The capacity of the vapor compression subsystem in the solar assisted air-conditioning system can be reduced to 19 kW from original 28 kW. The economic performance of the solar desiccant dehumidification system is compared with a conventional air-conditioning system. The results show that the energy saving potentials of incorporating solar desiccant dehumidification system in conventional air-conditioning systems is significant for the Hong Kong weather conditions due to higher COP resulted from higher supply chilled water temperature from chillers. The annual operation energy savings for the hybrid system is 6760 kWh and the payback period of the hybrid system is around 7 years when the extra initial cost of the hybrid air-conditioning system is HK$6360. Considering the substantial annual energy savings and reasonable pay back period, the extra cost is acceptable.
